Project  Forests, along with water, are the most important natural resource base in 
Description  Lao  PDR.  The  formal  forestry  sector  contributes  about  5%  to  gross 
domestic product (GDP) and accounts for 34% of total export value, and 
even more of net foreign exchange earnings. But these trends have been 
accompanied by decline in forest cover from 70% in 1970 to approximately 
42% in 2000, resulting in vast areas of degraded forestland that can be 
brought  under  productive  forest  plantations.  Lao  PDR,  along  the  Lao 
Mekong Plains, has significant potential and comparative advantage over 
its  neighbors  to  develop  financially  viable  forest  plantations  subsector 
because  of:  (i)  suitable  climate  and  site  conditions  for  growing  trees; 
(ii) low population density; (iii) vast areas of degraded forestland; (iv) flat or 
undulating  terrain;  (v)  an  existing  road  infrastructure  that  is  being 
upgraded; (vi) access to large markets in neighboring countries; (vii) low 
costs for land lease; and (viii) competitive costs for labor and inputs. The 
Project will establish a new institution, the Lao Plantation Authority (LPA), 
which  will  spearhead  efficient  and  sustainable  development  of  the 
plantations subsector in Lao PDR, combined with livelihood improvement 
and poverty reduction. It will provide full-package service to livelihood and 
enterprise plantations and one-window service to facilitate operations of 
multinational companies to develop industrial plantations. LPA will be a 
financially viable and self-sustaining institution. 
   
Rationale  The Industrial Tree Plantation Project (ITPP) was rated “unsuccessful” in 
the recent project completion report, as it could not meet its designed 
outcome. Reasons include: (i) inappropriate site selection, (ii) poor quality 
planting stock, (iii) inadequate skills among Department of Forestry (DOF) 
staff, (iv) subsidized credit prone to abuse, (v) inadequate and ill-timed 
expert inputs, and (vi) insufficient supervision by the Asian Development 
Bank  (ADB).  However,  ITPP  has  established  that:  (i)  efficient  forest 
plantations of all sizes are financially viable, and (ii) existing Government 
institutions have inadequate capacity to provide effective support to this 
important  and  emerging  subsector.  During  the  preparation  and 
implementation of ITPP, it was assumed that the capacity of DOF could be 
strengthened to provide the necessary support to forest plantations. The 
experience of ITPP has demonstrated that supporting forest plantations is 
a  highly  specialized  task  that  requires  a  different  set  of  skills  and 
operational modalities than required for natural forest management, which

ii 
is the mainstay of DOF’s experience and expertise. Plantations form a 
niche  subsector;  individual  staff  and  institutions  require  specific  and 
proven capacity from raising nurseries to marketing plantation products. 
Similarly, the financing of forest plantations requires a specific lending 
product—equity  financing  or  full-term  credit—for  which  assessment, 
delivery, and collection have to be synchronized with the establishment, 
production, and felling cycles of plantations. Taking medium-term loans is 
impractical as there is no interim income to service interest payments 
during the 8-year rotation. Furthermore, the Agricultural Promotion Bank, 
established in 1994, was in no position then or now to cope with the 
demands and requirements of this subsector. 
 
An ineffective land-use planning and tenure system continue to constrain 
the development of livelihood and large-scale industrial plantations. The 
current 3-year term for a temporary land-use certificate, which can be 
rolled over, requires formal confirmation and registration. This process is 
constrained by inadequate capacity of existing Government institutions, 
although it is provided for by the Land Law. It is essential that issuance of 
land-use certificates is synchronized with the plantation rotation cycle. LPA 
will set up a land registry and facilitate the issuance of land-use certificates 
to  livelihood  planters  after  they  have  established  their  credentials  as 
serious operators at the end of the first 8-year rotation. 
 
The relevant rules and regulations need refinement and clarification. Land-
lease  agreement  negotiations  with  the  Government,  for  industrial 
plantations,  are  time-consuming  and  foreign  direct  investment  (FDI) 
procedures  in  this  subsector  are  not  always  transparent.  Plantation 
management guidelines—appropriate to the scale/type of plantations—
should be developed and made operational. In particular, harvesting and 
transit rules need to be rationalized to avoid marketing and delivery delays 
and  minimize  rent-seeking  opportunities.  Similarly,  plantation  logs  and 
woodchips should be exempted from export duties and restrictions so that 
the foreign exchange earning potential of the subsector is fully realized.  
 
Current institutional and staff capacity constraints are preventing Lao PDR 
from (i) developing a vibrant plantations subsector, and (ii) capturing the 
economic  development  potential  of  its  land  and  water  resources.  The 
Forest Plantations Development Project (the Project), by establishing LPA, 
will  address  these  institutional,  human  resource,  and  technological 
constraints. LPA will provide the necessary support to all types of clients 
efficiently, and will facilitate the enforcement of environmental and social 
safeguards.  
   
Impact and  The  impact  of  the  Project  will  contribute  to  steady  economic  growth, 
Outcome  accelerated poverty reduction, and improved environmental conservation. 
As  a  direct  outcome  of  the  Project,  an  efficient  and  equitable  forest 
plantations subsector would take off. The Project will reduce poverty of 
participating  households,  create  a  substantial  plantation  resource,  and 
catalyze large-scale international private investment in plantations that will 
lead  to  the  development  of  a  modern  wood  processing  industry.  The 
Project will achieve its objectives by: (i) establishing a semiautonomous,

iii 
sustainable, and efficient new institution to support the development of this 
subsector; and (ii) supporting financially viable livelihood and enterprise 
plantations, and facilitating the establishment of industrial plantations and 
the associated processing industry. The Project will reduce poverty by: 
(i) generating  income  and  employment  opportunities  for  unskilled  and 
semiskilled  rural  poor;  (ii)  creating  assets  for  poor  households;  and 
(iii) raising substantial revenues and foreign exchange for the Government 
to improve the country’s fiscal and balance of payments situation.

$15.35  million  equivalent,  consisting  of  foreign  exchange  costs  of 
$6.45 million (42%) and local currency costs of $8.90 million (58%).

Implementation  MAF will be the executing agency pending formal establishment of LPA 
Arrangements  following  approval  of  LPA  decree.  Once  operational,  LPA  will  be  the 
executing  agency.  LPA  will  have  a  board  of  directors  (BOD),  a  high-

iv 
ranking Government official as its managing director, and a professional 
chief  technical  advisor  (CTA).  Its  operations  will  be  divided  into  four 
divisions, nine units, and a public relations office. Each division will be 
headed  by  a  director.  The  Livelihood  and  Industrial  Plantations  are 
executing  divisions,  while  the  Land  Survey  and  Finance  and  Human 
Resources are support divisions. As a semiautonomous agency, the BOD 
will be empowered by the Government, through a prime ministerial decree, 
to implement LPA’s mandate. BOD will approve: (i) appointment of LPA 
staff; (ii) LPA’s quarterly, annual, and long-term work plans; (iii) land-lease 
agreements for enterprise and industrial plantations; and (iv) business 
proposals for setting up processing industries. The BOD will be chaired by 
the Vice Minister of MAF. Other relevant line agencies will be represented 
by deputy director generals or an official of higher rank. LPA will be run 
like a corporate body, and annual financial and technical audits will be 
carried out by external auditors. It will issue an annual report. 
   
Procurement  Goods  and  services  financed  from  the  ADB  loan  and  grant  will  be 
procured in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. Vehicles, 
equipment, civil works, and materials will be procured by international 
competitive  bidding  where  the  cost  is  valued  at  more  than  $500,000 
equivalent, or by international shopping where the cost is valued from 
$100,000 to $500,000 equivalent. Where several local suppliers can offer 
satisfactory service facilities, then vehicles, equipment, civil works, and 
materials valued at less than $100,000 equivalent may be procured under 
local competitive bidding procedures, or through direct purchase. Final 
details for procurement will be determined during project implementation 
as appropriate. To commence the Project on time, ADB has approved, at 
the  Government’s  request,  advance  action  for  procurement.  The 
Government has been advised that approval of such advance action does 
not commit ADB to finance any part of the Project. 
   
Staffing   At full strength by year-3, LPA will have a total of 40 management and 
professional staff. During the first 12–18 months after its inception, LPA 
will be staffed in stages according to its work plan. An interim-CTA (iCTA) 
will be recruited for about 6 months, and will be responsible for searching 
and short listing candidates for the tenured CTA position. All staff positions 
will be filled with qualified individuals, as defined against each position, 
following  a  transparent  process.  The  iCTA/CTA  will  be  empowered  to 
search,  shortlist,  interview,  and  select  staff.  BOD  will  approve  the 
recruitment of selected candidate(s) after LPA receives concurrence from 
ADB and the Government of Malaysia. Four internationally recruited staff 
will be engaged (252 person-months). The iCTA/CTA will be offered a 
competitive  package,  comparable  to  those  provided  by  similar  private 
sector  multinationals  and  development  agencies.  Three  experts,  to 
supervise 3 divisional directors, will be seconded by the Government of 
Malaysia. Some 35 nationally recruited professional staff (2,520 person-
months)  and  24  support  staff  (1,728  person-months)  will  be  offered 
employment packages comparable with those provided by multinational 
companies operating in Lao PDR, in order to attract and retain highly 
skilled staff.

v 
 
Suitably qualified Lao nationals will be engaged as directors of divisions 
and will work under the supervision of respective international experts and 
the CTA. A staff transition plan will be prepared at the outset to include 
necessary on-the-job and short-term training of Lao staff to take on the 
responsibilities without the supervision of international experts starting in 
years 4–5 of project implementation. However, it is anticipated that an 
international CTA may be required even beyond project completion. 
   
Project Benefits  The Project’s core interventions in livelihood, enterprise, and industrial 
and Beneficiaries  plantations  will  have  significant  impact  on  the  income  of  participating 
planters  and  entrepreneurs.  Small  livelihood  plantations  (SLPs), 
established on 9,500 hectares (ha), will be financially viable, create full-
time  employment  for  the  2,000  participating households,  and  increase 
their cash income within the first year from $150 to $385 per ha per 
annum. This increase will pull average household’s total annual income 
above the food poverty line of $738 (footnote 19). A typical household with 
5 ha allocation will be pulled above the food poverty line with a constant 
stream of income from labor inputs on their own plantations for the next 
5 years. LPA will compensate them for their labor inputs as part of its 
equity  in  SLPs.  From  years  8–12,  household  will  receive  on  average 
$858/ha/year income as its share of the revenues. These revenues will 
more than double their total annual household income and increase their 
cash income by six times. In the process, livelihood plantations will create 
a resourceful asset for poor households, for which they will receive land-
use certificate at the end of first 8-year rotation. This increase in income 
and asset creation will have significant impact on poverty reduction and 
the general well-being of the average household. With this level of cash 
income,  the  household  will  be  able  to  afford  basic  education,  primary 
healthcare,  and  more  nutritious  food.  The  multiplier  effect—with  more 
opportunities for trade and employment—could dramatically change the 
socioeconomic profiles of participating villages within 8–10 years. 
 
Even if only half the expressions of interest from multinational companies 
materialize, the pace of development in the plantations subsector would 
be significant. Conservative estimates show that as much as 150,000 ha 
may be under industrial plantations by 2015. This scale of development 
would create massive employment opportunities. Even 10,000 ha/year of 
plantation development will create 1 million person-days employment. This 
would result in labor shortages, requiring increasingly mechanized means 
of  plantation  management.  This  transformation  would  lead  to  higher 
wages, jobs with better skills, and a significant multiplier effect on regional 
and national economies. 
   
Risks and  Establishment  of  LPA  and  large-scale  development  of  the  forest 
Assumptions  plantations subsector would entail political, institutional, market, business, 
financial, and environmental risks. The establishment of LPA is a unique 
development  in  Lao  PDR  and  is  a  high-risk  high-return  investment. 
However,  all  these  risks—individually  as  well  as  collectively—can  be 
managed  and  mitigated.  LPA  would  be  able  to  effectively  mitigate  all 
except the political risk. There are two types of political risks: one would be

vi 
faced by LPA itself and the other by Lao PDR. To mitigate the political risk 
faced  by  Lao  PDR,  ADB  could  provide  a  political  risk  guarantee  to 
qualified foreign investors. But mitigation of political risk for the LPA would 
depend on the Government’s commitment to allow LPA to practice its 
autonomy without interference. By approving a prime ministerial decree for 
establishing LPA, the Government will demonstrate its commitment to LPA 
as  a  semiautonomous  body.  The  Government  has  provided  specific 
assurances,  and  key  triggers  have  been  covenanted  in  the  Loan 
Agreement, to stall and/or withdraw support in case LPA does not operate 
in  accordance  with  its  agreed  design.  ADB  and  the  Government  of 
Malaysia  will  provide  close  supervision  by  deploying  skilled  and 
experienced international experts in LPA’s formative years. ADB will also 
provide active and rigorous project supervision to ensure that political risk 
is effectively mitigated.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan, and (ii) a proposed grant, both to Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) for the 
Forest Plantations Development Project (the Project). The project processing chronology is in 
Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
1.  Forest Sector and the National Economy 
2.  The total land area of Lao PDR is 236,800 square kilometers (km2) and the present 
forest cover is approximately 42%. About 25,000 km2 (2.5 million hectares [ha]) are designated 
production  forests  and  another  35,000  km2  have  potential  for  commercial  production.  The 
remaining 80,000 km2 are classed forest fallow and scrub. Although the predominant economic 
sector of Lao PDR is agriculture—involving 85% of the country’s 5.6 million people—in some 
rural areas, forest resource exploitation can be one of the few available economic activities. For 
many rural poor, non-timber forest products (NTFPs) may provide more than half the household 
income. The water sector is also of vital importance to the economy for irrigation, hydropower, 
and fish resources. Water, in turn, is heavily dependent on forests for protecting catchments 
from soil erosion and maintaining seasonal water flow. 
 
3.  The formal forestry sector contributes about 5% of the gross domestic product (GDP) 
and accounts for 34% of total export value, and even more of net foreign exchange earnings. 
Sawn wood was the most valuable export product, but the wood industry was predominately 
based on logs from natural forests and industrial capacity exceeded long-term sustainable 
annual allowable cut. As a result, the Government introduced a ban on the export of logs in 
2000 and the harvest of natural wood decreased from 730,000 cubic meters (m3) in 1999 to 
200,000 m3 in 2001. Government revenues from log royalties have decreased from 20% in the 
mid-1990s to 6% of tax revenues and 5% of all revenues in 2000. No data is available on 
specific financial values deriving from forest plantations, but the contribution is still small. A 
number of foreign-funded projects have provided technical assistance (TA) and investment 
financing to the forestry sector since the late 1970s (Appendix 2). 
 
2.  Sector Strategies 
4.  The  Government’s  Socio-Economic  Development  Strategy  for  2020  forecasts  GDP 
growth of 7% per annum. By 2010, the Government aims to reduce poverty by half from its 
current level of 39%. Furthermore, there is a national commitment to attain 70% forest cover by 
2020—accomplished through forest rehabilitation and planting. Therefore, in formulating the 
National Growth and Poverty Eradication Strategy (NGPES)2, the Government attached great

5.  NGPES aspires to meet its objectives through natural resource development. Future 
growth-enhancing investments and development priorities, which reflect the economic potential 
of the country’s natural resource base, have been identified as means to increase national 
revenues and eradicate poverty. Hydropower, mining, tourism, and wood- and agro-processing 
industries are the highest priorities for such investments. Royalties and taxes to the Government 
will comprise the bulk of the revenues generated by these investments. Emphasis will be placed 
on  promoting  economic  growth  centers  throughout  the  country  to  further  develop  the  rich 
endowment of natural resources including land, water, forest, and biodiversity. This includes the 
identification and delineation of regions to better integrate economic, infrastructure, trade, and 
services development. Macroeconomic stability, private sector development, trade facilitation, 
and regional integration policies and strategies all feed into expanding this resource base to 
promote economic growth nationwide. 
 
6.  Recently,  the  Government  adopted  the  comprehensive  Forest  Strategy  2020.3  This 
strategy consolidates the Government’s vision and related policies to develop the forestry sector 
and plantations subsector on a sustainable basis. To implement NGPES and Forest Strategy 
2020, the Government wishes to promote both private and public sector investments in forest 
plantations development. The objective is to develop the plantations subsector on a large scale 
to  create  substantial  supply  of  industrial  raw  material  and  generate  employment.  This  will 
eventually lead to the expansion of the country’s wood-processing industry and enable Lao PDR 
to become a major supplier of wood products to international markets, which are experiencing 
an increasing deficit of wood and fiber supplies. To mobilize the necessary financial resources, 
the  Government  aims  to  promote  foreign  direct  investment  (FDI)  in  the  forest  plantations 
subsector.  The  Government  also  encourages  the  participation  of  poor  households  in 
establishing forest plantations for livelihoods by allocating suitable lands in rural areas. 
 
3.  Sector Policies and Regulations 
7.  There  are  about  26  pieces  of  legislation—foreign  investment,  business,  tax, 
environmental, land, water, and forest laws, decrees, regulations, and orders—that govern 
different  aspects  of  forest  plantations  and  associated  industrial  processing  in  Lao  PDR. 
Therefore, establishing forest plantations in the country entails compliance with a complex 
regulatory framework. The plantation development process, from land allocation to harvesting 
and marketing of logs, is covered by multiple regulations enforced by different Government 
agencies and departments. About 12 licenses, permits, and approvals are required at various 
stages. Many of these are linked to the size of the land area, as larger plantation areas require 
higher-level approval. The regulations derive from various laws, subsidiary decrees, and orders 
from several different ministries. Some of the approvals or licenses must be obtained before 
application can be made for others, so it is not possible to secure all of them at one time from 
one place. Nonetheless, Lao PDR has an adequate set of policies and regulations to govern 
development of the forest plantations subsector. A comprehensive review of the relevant laws, 
decrees, regulations, and orders, as well as a proposed policy and regulatory framework, are 
provided in Supplementary Appendix A.

8.  ADB's  Policy  on  Forestry  (1995)  identifies  plantations  as  a  sustainable  and 
environmentally  sound  source  of  industrial  raw  material  and  means  for  enhancing  rural 
employment opportunities and household incomes. It recommends the establishment of fast-
growing, high-yielding tree plantations in selected degraded forests and grasslands with the 
involvement of the private sector (corporations, communities, and individual households). It 
recommends  a  participatory  process  involving  primary  project  beneficiaries  and  relevant 
stakeholders in establishing land tenure status, site and species selection, and decisions on 
plantation silviculture and management regimes. The Lao PDR Country Strategy and Program 
Update, 2005–2006 identifies the forest plantations subsector as having significant potential to 
diversify traditional subsistence agriculture in the country. 
 
4.  Forest Plantations Development 
9.  Planting of fast-growing exotic tree species (e.g., Eucalyptus and Acacia) for industrial 
purposes started in Lao PDR about 10 years ago. The ADB-supported Industrial Tree Plantation 
Project (ITPP)4 pioneered this development and established about 9,000 ha in Vientiane Capital 
and  Vientiane,  Bolikhamxay,  Khammuane,  Savannakhet,  Saravane,  and  Champasack 
provinces.5 Since 1999, additional plantations have been established through the Government's 
replanting schemes. The current total area of forest plantations in Lao PDR has been estimated 
at 95,000 ha.6 But most of these consist of teak plantations in the northern provinces. Forest 
Strategy 2020 has an ambitious goal of establishing plantations on 500,000 ha by 2020. The 
target  for  each  of  the  seven  ITPP  provinces  is  around  50,000  ha  in  the  same  period. 
Development of livelihood plantations is an effective way to reduce poverty because it helps the 
Government implement NGPES and Forest Sector Strategy 2020, generate employment, create 
assets, and provide additional and alternative sources of income for poor households. 
 
5.  Wood Processing Industry 
10.  Compared with other countries, the wood processing industry is small, with annual sawn 
wood and plywood production of approximately 250,000 m3, mainly using logs from natural 
forest. Forest plantations also produce sawlogs (20–45 cm diameter) and pulplogs (10–20 cm 
diameter). The latter are the predominant output at present, as the plantations are still young. 
Although  processing  of  plantation  logs  commenced  less  than  5  years  ago,  there  are  two 
vertically integrated factories in the Vientiane area focusing on plantation grown logs. The 
combined capacity is approximately 3,000 m3 per annum. But insufficient kiln drying capacity 
and raw material supply is causing underutilization of capacity. Despite such problems, these 
factories have secured contracts with international companies that distribute a wide range of 
value-added wood products throughout the world. However, the subsector is not competitive 
internationally because: (i) insufficient capacity does not make it a credible supplier, (ii) it lacks 
critical manufacturing mass, and (iii) transport costs are high. Because of these constraints, 
which  all  relate  to  lack  of  economies  of  scale,  production  of  sawn  timber  products  from 
Eucalyptus camaldulensis is barely profitable.

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  Weak Institutional Capacity 
11.  The Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry (MAF) is the main national level institution 
responsible for all aspects of forestry administration, including inspection. During 2001–2002, 
MAF was reorganized by establishing three new institutions: (i) Technical and Science Council 
of Agriculture and Forestry, (ii) National Agriculture and Forestry Research Institute (NAFRI), 
and  (iii) National  Agriculture  and  Forestry  Extension  Service  (NAFES).  The  reorganization 
transferred all agriculture and forestry research activities to NAFRI, and all agriculture and 
forestry extension activities (including ITPP and extension projects) to NAFES. However, the 
Department of Forestry (DOF) maintains responsibility for administering and regulating the 
forest plantations subsector. MAF is now composed of 12 departments/units, of which seven 
have  cross-cutting  responsibilities  for  different  aspects  of  forestry  administration.  DOF  is 
responsible for forests, plantations, and wood industry administrative matters and activities, 
including inspection. DOF is organized in three divisions and two sections. NAFES has three 
sections  (extension  and  project  management,  administration  and  planning,  and  rural 
development) and two subsector training centers (livestock, and agriculture and forestry). In 
mid-2005,  NAFES  reorganized  its  Provincial/District  Agriculture  and  Forestry  Extension 
Services (PAFES/DAFES); the primary interface between MAF, villages, and farmers. PAFES 
has technical staff in charge of sector work for livestock, agriculture, forestry, and irrigation.  
 
12.  At the provincial level, there are Provincial Agriculture and Forestry Offices (PAFOs).7 At 
the field level, forestry administration is carried out by the village committees in charge of tax 
collection. PAFOs are divided into seven sections, of which the Provincial Forestry Office and 
PAFES are primarily concerned with forestry matters. 
 
13.  The overall capacity of all agricultural institutions is weak. Those that deal with the 
forestry sector are no exception. The modest capacity that exists in the forestry institutions 
mainly deals with the management of natural forests. The forest plantations require different 
sets of training and skills ranging from land-use planning to site selection, raising modern 
nursery stock, extension, and marketing. Forestry institutions, at all levels in the Government, 
are neither geared nor motivated to undertake such a complex set of tasks. Under ITPP, TA 
was provided to create such capacity but it could not create the requisite critical mass of 
expertise. Most of the current NAFES and DOF staff do not have the skills for such tasks. The 
appropriately  educated  and  motivated  individuals  do  not  work  for  Government  institutions 
because of lack of incentives and commensurate compensation. In other countries, where 
plantations subsectors have done well, autonomous and specialized institutions were set up to 
handle the tasks—Fiji Pine Company of Fiji; Sabah Softwoods Inc. in Sabah, Malaysia; and 
Federal Land Development Authority (FELDA) of Malaysia. On the other hand, institutions that 
were created within the department or at arm’s-length of the department (Perhutani of Indonesia 
and Forest Industry Organization of Thailand) are not as successful and/or efficient.

3.  Lessons Learned and Related Constraints 
15.  The recent ITPP project completion report (PCR)9 rated it “unsuccessful.” ITPP could not 
meet its designed outcome due to the following reasons: (i) poor site selection, (ii) bad quality 
planting stock, (iii) inadequate skills among DOF staff, (iv) subsidized credit prone to abuse, 
(v) inadequate and ill-timed expert inputs, and (vi) insufficient supervision by ADB. During the 
preparation and implementation of ITPP, it was assumed that the capacity of DOF could be 
strengthened to provide the necessary support to forest plantations. The outcome of ITPP has 
demonstrated that supporting forest plantations is a highly specialized task that requires an 
entirely different set of skills. Forest plantation development is a niche subsector; individual staff 
and  institutions  need  to  have  specific  and  proven  capacity  for  land-use  planning,  nursery 
raising, planters’ training, financial management, and marketing. Under ITPP, DOF selected 
many sites that were spread out too thinly over a large area. Therefore, most of the plantations 
were not established in blocks. Several sites had inappropriate soil conditions; many were acidic 
and/or had hard pans. Despite the guidelines provided under ITPP, DOF was not able to 
undertake  appropriate  land-use  planning,  resulting  in  fragmented  plantations  established 
without soil testing and proper land preparation. Geographical spread of livelihood plantations 
substantially increased the cost of extension and marketing. 
 
16.  The subsidized credit line, extended through the Agricultural Promotion Bank (APB), was 
abused by many borrowers by either not planting the full area declared or not planting at all. The 
amount of credit per hectare was also set 25–35% higher than the actual cost of plantation 
establishment in most cases. In addition, APB had inadequate technical capacity to deal with 
such a Project and effectively manage the line of credit. The plantation financing required a 
specific lending product (i.e., a full-term loan), for which assessment, delivery, and collection 
have to be synchronized with the establishment, production, and felling cycles of plantations. 
Moreover, the interest payments, required from the outset, were also a burden since no cash 
income is generated from plantations in the interim years. APB was established in 1994 and 
was in no position, then or now, to cope with the demands and requirements of this subsector. 
 
17.  The expert inputs for ITPP were inadequate to begin with and were also ill-timed. Most 
of the technical inputs were already exhausted even before sizeable planting started in year-3 
(1997) of the Project. ADB changed its project officers frequently and missions were not fielded 
regularly  at  appropriate  stages  of  the  Project.  The  PCR  rated  ADB’s  performance  as 
“unsatisfactory.” 
 
18.   Land tenure for plantations, for both small livelihood and large industrial plantations, 
requires refinements. The Government now has a policy by which the 3-year term of temporary 
land-use certificates (TLUCs) can be extended. However, it is important that land tenure allows 
livelihood planters transfer of user rights in the interim and grants land ownership after they

LLA negotiations with the Government are time-consuming and the procedures for FDI in this

19.  An important precursor to resolving the issues of land tenure and LLA is land-use 
planning and zoning according to land capabilities. Geographic information systems (GISs), 
geo-positional satellite (GPS) devices, and satellite imagery provide powerful yet efficient and 
cost-effective tools to aide in land-use planning and zoning. The Forest Inventory and Planning 
Division, within DOF, has limited capacity to deal with these tasks. A GIS database of suitable 
lands for plantations must be developed, taking into account: (i) technical, environmental, and 
social criteria; (ii) land use for protection and production forests and agriculture; (iii) population 
density and levels of poverty; (iv) existing transport infrastructure and wood processing industry; 
and (v) access to markets, etc. 
 
20.  In  summary,  ITPP  demonstrated  that:  (i)  due  to  inappropriate  site  selection  and 
inadequate farmer training and support services, average productivity of ITPP plantations is less 
than half the potential mean annual increment (MAI) of 20 m3/ha/year; (ii) productive plantations 
are financially viable thus do not require subsidized credit; (iii) there is a need to provide full-
term  credit  (or  other  form  of  financing)  that  matures  at  the  end  of  plantation  rotation; 
(iv) extending the line of credit through APB is inefficient due to its weak capacity and lack of 
motivation;  (v)  output  markets  do  not  yet  function  efficiently  and  planters  are  duped  by 
intermediaries into selling logs at throwaway prices because of lack of knowledge and limited 
choice;  and  (vi)  land  tenure  issues  require  further  refinements.  However,  the  two  main 
conclusions are that: (i) well established and well managed plantations can be financially viable, 
and (ii) existing Government institutions have inadequate capacity to provide effective support to 
this  subsector.  Therefore,  the  experience  of  ITPP  shows  that  the  future  success  of  small 
livelihood  plantations  (SLPs)  will  depend  on  coordinated  technical,  financial,  and  market 
support. In short, institutions must provide an efficient, full-package service to its clients. 
 
21.  Similarly, the growing and tangible interest of multinational companies in this subsector, 
to establish large industrial plantations (LIPs), should be facilitated by a well equipped and 
technically  skilled  institution.  This  process  in turn  depends  on  coordinated  support  from  a 
number of relevant Government agencies to issue all the necessary permits, licenses, and 
approvals. Such a coordinated service can be effectively provided through an institution that 
provides one-window service to interested private sector investors. 
 
22.  The  efficient  development  of  a  financially  viable  plantation  subsector—which  will 
significantly contribute to poverty reduction, economic growth, and government revenues—
would mainly depend on resolving land availability and land allocation issues efficiently. As 
shown by ITPP, existing institutions and capacity will not be able to support plantations any 
better than in the past. Hence, there is a need to develop suitable alternative institutional 
arrangements as part of the Project. 
 
4.  Opportunities 
23.  Estimates of growth potential for Eucalyptus spp. under ITPP indicate that the MAI for an 
8-year rotation is 6–24 m3/ha/year, depending on site conditions and management practices. At 
current prices and costs, a yield of at least 16 m3/ha/year is required for the plantation to be

7 
financially  viable.  Therefore,  close  attention  has  to  be  paid  to  site  selection  and  efficient 
management. MAI registered in other Eucalyptus camaldulensis trial plots, under ITPP, was 
7-27 m3/ha/year. Recent data from NAFRI’s 10-year old stands in the research area in Nam 
Xouang (Vientiane Capital) has shown MAI of 35 m3/ha/year for Acacia auriculiformis and 30 
m3/ha/year for the best Eucalyptus urophylla. 
 
24.  Continued steady economic growth in Lao PDR will increase demand for an expanding 
range of forest products. Similarly, economic growth in Thailand and Viet Nam, which has 
resumed following the financial crisis of 1997–98, combined with rapid economic growth in the 
People’s Republic of China and India, is creating substantial growth in demand for wood and 
wood  products,  including  woodchips,  pulp,  paper,  and  furniture.  Lao  PDR,  along  the  Lao 
Mekong  plains,  has  a  clear  comparative  advantage  over  its  neighbors  and  considerable 
potential  to  develop  a  commercially  viable  forest  plantations  subsector,  because  it  has: 
(i) suitable climate and site conditions for growing trees;10 (ii) low population density;11 (iii) vast 
areas of degraded forest land; (iv) flat or undulating terrain; (v) an existing road infrastructure 
that is being upgraded; (vi) access to large markets in neighboring countries; (vii) low costs for 
land lease; and (viii) competitive costs for labor and inputs. To take advantage of global demand 
and its enormous potential, Lao PDR needs to develop the plantations subsector efficiently. 
 
25.  Following completion of TA 3794–LAO12 in March 2003, it became evident that new 
institutional arrangements would be needed to overcome constraints that contributed to the 
unsatisfactory  performance  of  the  majority  of  plantations  established  under  ITPP.  It  was 
recognized  that  a  new  institution  had  to  be  established  to  develop  a  vibrant  plantations 
subsector  in  Lao  PDR.  Based  on  the  successful  experiences  of  regional  countries,  ADB 
proposed to set up the Lao Plantation Authority (LPA).13 To further explore the options of 
institutional and subsector development, the Government set up an Interministerial Working 
Group (IWG) in May 2004 comprising high-ranking officials from 11 line agencies. To better 
understand  the  relevant  existing  institutions  and  corporate  models  in  the  region,  in 
November 2004,  ADB  organized  a  regional  study  tour  for  IWG  to  three  countries 
(i.e., Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand). Many public organizations, in tandem with private 
companies, have successfully supported livelihood, enterprise, and industrial plantations in the 
region. Their models have a variety of institutional structures but most have autonomous or 
semiautonomous management. During the regional study tour, IWG closely observed a variety 
of institutions and management models to determine which was suitable for Lao PDR. It was 
most impressed by FELDA of Malaysia. 
 
26.  To tap the significant potential of this subsector, there is a need to create additional staff 
as  well  as  institutional  capacity  within  the  Government.  The  existing  institutions  are  not 
adequately  staffed  and  do  not  have  the  necessary  skills  and  experience  to  develop  this

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
28.  The impact of the Project will contribute to steady economic growth, accelerated poverty 
reduction, and improved environmental conservation. The immediate Project objective is to 
develop  an  efficient  and  equitable  forest  plantations  subsector  by:  (i)  establishing  a 
semiautonomous, sustainable, and efficient new institution to support the development of this 
subsector;  and  (ii)  supporting  financially  viable  livelihood  and  enterprise  plantations,  and 
facilitating the establishment of industrial plantations and the associated processing industry. 
The Project will contribute to poverty reduction by generating income and employment, creating 
assets for poor households, and raising considerable revenues for the Government. The Project 
will  create  a  substantial  plantation  resource  base  and  catalyze  large-scale  FDI  in  forest 
plantations, leading to the development of a modern wood processing industry in the medium 
term.  Plantations  will  be  established  on  degraded  forestlands  (DFL)  that  have  little  or  no 
alternative economic value. The project design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 3. 
 
B.  Outputs

and  efficient  new  institution,  within  MAF,  to  support  development  of  the  subsector.  LPA’s 
business plan will comprise four activities: (i) undertake land-use planning; (ii) support SLPs; 
(iii) facilitate  operations  of  LIPs;  and  (iv)  promote  plantation  enterprise  development  by 
supporting medium enterprise plantations (MEPs) and small and medium-sized enterprises 
(SMEs).  The  first  activity,  land-use  planning,  is  the  key  to  the  success  of  subsector

30.  Project Scope. One of the main reasons ITPP was not able to provide effective support 
to planters was that its scope was spread too thinly over seven provinces. Under this Project, 
SLPs will be established in three clusters of about 3,000–3,500 ha each in four provinces, 
i.e., Vientiane Capital, Bolikhamxay, Saravane, and Champasack, covering 9,500 ha. These 
three SLP clusters will be established within a 25–30 km radius with one nursery, extension 
support, and research and development center for each. Such clusters would provide a critical 
mass of plantations within financially viable proximity. Therefore, LPA will be able to provide 
effective support for training and marketing and supplying planting and protection material. The 
output from each cluster will eventually provide enough raw materials to support a 30,000 m3 
per annum capacity medium-density fiberboard plant in the vicinity. Such investments in the 
processing industry will follow after raw material supplies have been ensured. These clusters, 
therefore, will turn out to be efficient economic zones creating new business opportunities for 
upstream and downstream businesses. The site selection criteria and plantation development 
strategy are in Appendix 4. 
 
31.  Support for livelihood and enterprise plantations in two other provinces (Khammuane 
and Savannakhet) will be arranged through LIPs under the company-community model. The 
impending start of LIP development in these provinces will open opportunities for SLPs to be 
developed on the periphery of LIPs. Large plantation companies often provide training, planting 
material, and offer buy-back contracts to such communities in the vicinity of their operations in 
many countries (Indonesia, Brazil, Chile, etc.). LPA will develop such models in detail and 
facilitate their implementation. 
 
32.  Lao Plantation Authority. LPA will be set up through a prime ministerial decree as a 
semiautonomous body empowered to: (i) engage qualified staff at competitive salary packages 
set by itself; (ii) open and operate an imprest account(s), in foreign as well as local currencies, 
to manage grant and loan funds from ADB and the Government of Malaysia; (iii) open and 
operate corporate bank accounts, in foreign as well as local currencies, to manage its finances; 
(iv) be financially viable and charge for services rendered; (v) establish SLPs through equity-
sharing financing arrangements; (vi) recalibrate and refine its overall business and equity-
sharing models from time to time as may be deemed necessary due to changing circumstances; 
(vii) operate a revolving fund to support SLPs on continuing basis; and (viii) negotiate LLAs with 
LIPs on behalf of the Government. A detailed model of LPA has been prepared that describes 
its mission, structure, mandate, duties, powers and rights, staffing, business model, scope of 
work, operational costs, revenues, and cash flow (Supplementary Appendix A). LPA will provide 
full-package service to SLPs and MEPs and one-window service to LIPs. 
 
33.  Land-Use Planning. Identifying suitable DFL for all types and sizes of plantations will be 
the  first,  and  an  important,  activity  of  LPA.  It  is  critical  that  SLPs  are  established  within 
financially viable clusters where support for input supply, extension, and marketing is cost-

effective.  Due  to  the  bulky  nature  of  its  output,  haulage  costs  are  high.15  Therefore,  it  is 
imperative to develop the subsector in such a way that critical mass is created in a few selected

has already been completed. A GIS-based plantation atlas has been prepared that will be made 
available to all interested stakeholders on the Project’s web site. Three SLP clusters, in seven

criteria.  LPA  will  identify  suitable  lands  for  LIPs  (mainly  in  Khammuane  and  Savannakhet 
provinces) and MEPs, following a similar procedure. LPA will ensure that lands earmarked for 
forest plantations do not entail better alternative economic uses. 
 
34.  Small Livelihood Plantations. This activity will support the establishment of SLPs to 
improve the livelihood of poor households in the three target clusters. The aim is to support 
around 2,000 households in establishing financially viable plantations on 9,500 ha by providing 
a  full-package  service  through  an  equity-sharing  financing  model.  Each  household  will  be 
allocated on average 3–5 ha in blocks of 25–50 ha in the vicinity of their village. Land allocation 
will depend on labor availability and other economic activities of each household. LPA will 
identify qualified poor households following prescribed criteria and arrange for TLUCs following 
prevailing Government regulations, in consultation with the relevant local authorities. Planters 
will  be  explained  the  full  details  of  the  equity-sharing  financing  model,  training  program, 
concepts of clusters, and marketing support. Planters will be grouped according to their blocks 
to receive effective support from LPA and exchange information and help each other.

the Government with assistance from ADB in Vientiane in August 2004, turned out to be a 
watershed in the plantation development subsector in Lao PDR. This was the first occasion

by 2011, LIPs will have been established on at least 70,000 ha. Such strong expression of 
interest from multinational pulp and paper companies now provides the Government with a 
window of opportunity to entice significant FDI in this subsector.

2.  Environmental Management 
40.  The ITPP PCR noted that Eucalyptus plantations have not demonstrated any adverse 
impact on the environment. The plantation area to date has been a small portion of the overall 
forested area in these localities (a mere 0.5–5.0%) and this ratio will not change significantly

plantations, in terms of area coverage, will remain a modest part of the overall land-use pattern

41.  Monoculture plantations, if not managed properly, can cause harm to soil, water, flora, 
and  fauna.  The  Project’s  plantation  design,  development,  and  management  arrangements 
recognize the potential environmental issues associated with large-scale eucalyptus plantations. 
These include: (i) water use and quality; (ii) soil fertility; and (iii) pests, diseases, and fire risks.

warrant cause for concern. Rainfall in the Project area is 1,800–3,000 millimeters (mm) per 
year.  This  level  of  precipitation  is  more  than  adequate  to  support  Eucalyptus  plantations, 
especially when their density will be <10% of the overall land-use mosaic. Therefore, there is no 
risk of water shortages and/or lowering of water tables. Furthermore, plantation site selection, 
design and management principles, and standards outlined in the LPA’s Operations Manual 
(Supplementary Appendix C) are consistent with internationally recognized forest plantation 
certification  systems  and  technical  standards  and  guidelines  that  will  ensure  sustainable 
environmental management. These safeguards will effectively prevent and mitigate associated 
risks. LPA will have the requisite capacity to facilitate the enforcement of relevant standards and 
regulations by organizing third party audits. A summary initial environmental examination is in

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Project Benefits and Impacts 
63.  The Project’s core investments in SLPs, MEPs, and SMEs will have significant impact on 
the income of participating planters and entrepreneurs. Financially viable SLPs will create full-
time employment for the 2,000 participating households and more than double their annual cash

18 
income within the first year—from $150 to $384. A typical household with 5 ha allocation will be 
pulled above the food poverty line with a constant stream of cash income from labor inputs on 
their own plantations for the next 5 years (footnote 19). LPA will compensate participating 
households for their labor inputs as part of its equity in SLP. From years 8–12, households will 
receive on average over $858/ha/year income as its share of the revenues. These revenues will 
increase  their  household  cash  income  by  five  times.  In  the  process,  SLPs  will  create  a 
resourceful asset for poor households, who will receive LUCs after year-8 (end of the first 
rotation). Such an increase in income and asset creation will have significant impact not only on 
poverty reduction but also on the general well-being of the average household. With this level of 
cash income, the household will be able to afford basic education, primary health, and more 
nutritious food. The multiplier effect on the village economy, with more opportunities for trade 
and employment, will be just as important. The socioeconomic profile of participating villages 
could change dramatically within 8–10 years. More detailed financial and economic analysis is 
in Appendix 11. 
 
64.  Even if only half the expressions of interest from multinational companies materialize, 
the pace of development in the forest plantations subsector would be significant. Conservative

development will create one million person-days of employment. This situation would result in 
labor shortages, requiring increasingly mechanized means of plantation management. This 
transformation would result in higher labor wages, jobs with better skills, higher household 
income, and a significant multiplier effect on the regional and national economy.

generating land rent of $40,000. This estimate assumes land rent of $20/ha/year, which is a

generating land rents of $3 million per annum. This level of wood production would result in the

medium density fiberboards, and sawlogs.24

C.  Project Risks 
70.  The setting up of LPA and large-scale development of forest plantations subsector would 
entail political, institutional, market, business, financial, and environmental risks. But all these 
risks—individually as well as collectively—can be managed and mitigated. LPA would be able to 
effectively mitigate all risks, except political risk. There are two types of political risks. One 
would be faced by LPA itself and the other by Lao PDR. To mitigate the risk faced by Lao PDR, 
ADB could provide a political risk guarantee to qualified foreign investors. But mitigation of the 
LPA risk would mainly depend on the Government’s commitment to allow LPA to practice its 
autonomy without interference. The Government will provide a commitment at the highest level 
by approving the prime ministerial decree establishing LPA. The Government has also provided 
specific assurances that have been covenanted in the draft Loan Agreement. More detailed 
description of risks and their mitigation measures is in Appendix 13.

1.  Markets 
4.  For any production system, the input and output markets is a key factor. Therefore, the 
relationship between the production site and markets for the produce is critical. However, the 
nature of this relationship changes over time and varies with the product type. With forest 
production systems, there are a wide range of products that vary over time. For timber products, 
there is a price-size curve that is generally “S” shaped. Small logs, mainly used for fuelwood, 
have a low price, and medium logs for pulp or composite panel manufacture command a slightly 
higher price. Large logs, for sawmilling and manufacture of joinery, furniture and construction 
material, command a 30–35% higher price. Logs with diameter >50 centimeters (cm) command 
higher prices for certain species and special end uses. 
 
5.  The markets for each of these product categories also vary. Fuelwood is normally sold 
locally or consumed by the producers. But it may also be used for charcoal-making, which has a 
wide range of potential markets. High quality charcoal is shipped half way round the world. 
Pulpwood and chipwood are specialized markets and are dependent on processing capacity. 
Since there are generally few plants in the area, their location is known at the outset, so a 
haulage cost that enables the grower to achieve an acceptable price can be determined. At the 
same time, there are enormous economies of scale that apply to both pulp and composite panel 
manufacture, so processing plants tend to be large. The maximum distance for pulpwood for an 
existing pulp mill is dependent on distribution of existing plantations and available modes of 
transport. However, the large volumes required by a mill mean that an assured and large 
volume at a long distance may be preferable to a closer yet unreliable and scattered supply. 
 
6.  World demand for pulp and paper, hence wood fiber, is growing steadily and many 
multinational companies are planning to expand their capacity. Since many of their existing mills 
have limitations on their raw material supply, these companies are more likely to build new 
capacity wherever they can find new resources, rather than expand their existing plants. Thus, 
lack of an existing market for pulpwood within an economic distance does not exclude a site if 
there is sufficient potential for raw material within a reasonable radius of a site where a pulp mill 
could be set up in future. The same logic would apply to a medium density fiberboard (MDF) 
plant with a substantially lower raw material requirement than a pulp mill. 
 
7.  Part of the Project strategy is to promote a sufficiently large area of industrial plantations 
to attract 1–2 pulp mills and a few MDF plants to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao 
PDR) in the near future. It is possible to identify the most likely sites for such plants by applying 
criteria—accessibility, availability of labor, power, and water—that limit the choice of potential 
sites. Establishing plantations on speculation that a plant will be built in the future increases 
risks for planters. However, Lao Plantation Authority (LPA) will apply robust criteria to select 
appropriate sites for clusters and determine whether aggregate area within clusters would be 
sufficient to attract investments in processing plants by the private sector. Experience in other 
countries, where extensive plantations have been established without processing plants, shows 
that they follow once raw material supplies reach a critical mass. The advantage of forest 
plantations is that planters can leave the trees growing for a few more years until more attractive 
prices are offered. The trees, in the meantime, will continue to grow and add value. 
 
8.  An important factor related to location is the minimum plantation area required to ensure 
sustainable raw material supplies to a variety of processing plants. Markets are quickly emerging 
around the selected core clusters. Good all-weather roads permit vehicles to provide economical 
transport. The prevailing average roadside price around these clusters, $13.5 per cubic meter (m3), 
is enough to make a plantation with mean annual increment (MAI) of 16 m3/ha (yield class [YC] 16) 
financially viable. In 5–7 years, about 5,000 ha of productive plantations in each cluster could

2.  Site Conditions 
9.  Site selection is as important as the location. It means that DFL with suitable soil 
properties and appropriate hydrology and topography should be chosen for forest plantations. 
The following criteria will be applied in selecting DFL for forest plantations: (i) crown density 
must be <20%; (ii) lands within a designated National Biodiversity Conservation Area should be 
excluded; (iii) soil slope should be <20° to avoid risk of soil damage and erosion; and (iv) a safe 
distance,  about  100  m,  should  be  maintained  from  water  bodies  (streams,  lakes,  canals, 
watercourses). Sites with slopes >20° will be costlier to harvest in the future. From geographic 
information system (GIS) data and field surveys, it is clear that DFL on flatter land is not 
homogenous and includes a range of conditions from more or less grassland, through varying 
degrees of scrub and bush to secondary forest. Somewhere along the continuum, there would 
be a point at which the secondary forest is sufficiently well stocked with useful species that it 
should be left to regenerate naturally. LPA will survey such area and determine its classification, 
depending on a number of factors—size and diameter distribution of trees by species and their 
quality, and threats that may affect regeneration. 
 
10.  Having eliminated areas of DFL within National Biodiversity Conservation Areas—on 
steeper slopes, away from water bodies, with the capacity to regenerate naturally—attention 
should be paid to soil conditions. Acid, shallow and/or compacted, and unduly rocky soils should 
be avoided as these soils will reduce plant growth and require higher inputs of fertilizers and 
management. Only those soils that would ensure a YC16 or more should be selected. While 
selecting DFL for forest plantations, it would be important to consider alternative land uses. DFL 
that meet the above criteria, but have a high opportunity cost because they are suitable for uses 
that yield higher returns than forest plantations, should be excluded. This would exclude fertile 
and flatter lands near settlements where forestry activities are normally unable to compete. 
 
11.  Finally, the amount of suitable DFL that meets these criteria within a village, and/or 
within  a  group  of  neighboring  villages,  is  important.  In  order  to  minimize  market  risk  and 
maximize prices, it is imperative to establish forest plantations on at least 3,000–5,000 ha within 
a radius of about 25 kilometers (km) from an existing or potential site of a processing plant. 
Such a cluster of forest plantations should be able to supply 50,000–70,000 m3 annually in a 
sustainable manner. The total land area within a 25 km radius is about 200 km2 (200,000 ha), 
implying that forest plantations would only constitute <0.025% of the total area. 
 
12.  To provide a cost-effective extension service and capture economies of scale for future 
harvesting  and  marketing  of  plantation  logs,  LPA  will  select  villages  where  at  least  20 
households want to participate in a block of about 100 ha (assuming average DFL allocation of 
5 ha per household). This area will eventually produce a sustainable annual output of around 
2,000 m3 of timber, which is enough to fill 2–3 trucks every week. Some 3–4 such subclusters 
producing 6,000-8,000 m3 annually within a radius of 5–10 km would keep one truck fully 
occupied year-round hauling the produce 30–50 km to market. About 10 such subclusters within 
the wider radius of around 25 km would meet the minimum marketing requirements. Hence, a 
local transport industry would also evolve, creating more jobs and trade opportunities, and 
providing cost effective transport. An illustrative layout of SLP subclusters within the core cluster 
is provided in Figure A4.1.

3.  Labor Availability 
14.  Establishing and maintaining a forest plantation requires that a sufficient amount of labor 
is available, preferably from household members. Planters could use part of the cash equity 
financed by LPA to hire some casual labor, depending on the opportunity cost of family labor. 
Planters that are currently able to produce surplus agricultural commodities may prefer to hire 
casual labor, in which case family labor does not become a limiting factor. For poorer planters 
with low agricultural productivity, cash income for labor is likely to be more important. For such 
households, the allocation of DFL will be constrained by the number of family members that can 
work on plantations. Most plantation work is not particularly heavy, so it could be undertaken by 
women and teenage children. A typical calendar for farm labor requirement in the lower Mekong 
plains has been prepared to ascertain the availability of excess household labor and determine 
a possible conflict in timing of farm and plantation operations (Supplementary Appendix A). The 
calendar shows, a household of two adults and a teenage child cultivating one ha of paddy 
could easily establish and maintain a 5-ha plantation in 5 years (establishing 1 ha per year). As 
a guide, the following recommendations are made for allocating DFL based on household labor 
availability: 
(i)  households with only one available worker: 0.5 ha; 
(ii)  households with two available workers: 1.5 ha if planted in a single year or up to 
4 ha if planted over several years but not more than 0.8 ha per year; and 
(iii)  households with more than two available workers: 2–3 ha if planted in a single 
year or up to 5 ha if planted over 3–5 years.

poverty is one of the main criteria for selecting participating villages. However, poverty has 
several dimensions and causes; among them is remoteness, which implies lack of access to 
markets  and  social  services.  Some  communities  with  high  incidence  of  poverty  may  be 
excluded from the Project due to unsuitable soil quality and/or lack of access to markets. 
Experience  with  ITPP  has  shown  that  failure  to  achieve  a  reasonable  level  of  plantation 
productivity may actually aggravate poverty. Therefore, great care will be taken while dealing 
with communities where there is a high incidence of poverty but other criteria are not fully met.

POLITICAL RISK GUARANTEE FACILITY 
1.  In  addition  to  equity  and  debt  financing,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  also 
provides various types of credit enhancement products. Among them is political risk guarantee 
(PRG) which is provided to investors (for tier-two capital, i.e., shareholder loans and loan 
guarantees) and financial institutions to cover risks that they cannot easily absorb or manage on 
their own. Mitigating these risks can make a crucial difference in mobilizing long-term financing, 
especially for private sector projects. While ADB guarantees provide explicit protection against 
perceived political risks, investors and lenders also take comfort with the implicit protection 
afforded by ADB's involvement in a project (e.g., investment disputes between parties can be 
resolved quicker and more amicably). 
 
2.  Through this Project, the Government wishes to attract foreign direct investment (FDI) in 
the forest plantations subsector. Given the significant opportunities for FDI in this subsector, 
large amounts of financing will be required from investors and commercial lenders to achieve 
the Government’s development objectives. Because the Government does not have a long-
standing track record with FDI, investors and commercial lenders may require a PRG to protect 
their  loans  against  perceived  political  risks  associated  with  the  region,  the  Lao  People’s 
Democratic Republic (Lao PDR), and the forest plantations subsector. 
 
3.  Under this Project, a PRG facility (the Facility) will be established for investors and 
commercial lenders, covering eligible loans in the forest plantations subsector against perceived 
political risks in Lao PDR. The size of the Facility will be $400 million, backed by $200 million 
from ADB ordinary capital resources, and $200 million from external resources provided by 
commercial and official political risk insurers through reinsurance.1 ADB’s gross exposure in the 
Facility will be $400 million and net exposure will be $200 million. ADB’s net exposure will be 
counter-guaranteed by the Government. The Guaranteed Percentage will be up to 100%. The 
term of each PRG will be up to 30 years. 
 
4.  The purpose of the Facility is to enable ADB to respond more flexibly to requests from 
investors  and  financial  institutions  for  its  guarantee  instruments,  without  compromising  its 
environmental policies and procedures, and social safeguards. Under the Facility, ADB will 
provide PRG to investors and commercial lenders (Guarantee Holders) covering eligible loans. 
PRG will guarantee payment of debt as a result of the following risks: currency inconvertibility 
and  or  non-transfer,  expropriation,  breach  of  contract,  and  political  violence  (including 
terrorism). The Facility will not cover commercial risks. 
 
5.  The annual fee for each PRG will be paid by the Guarantee Holder. The fee will be 
market-based. The Guarantee Holder will also pay a one-time front-end fee of up to 1%. ADB 
will require reinsurers to have a minimum investment rating to be acceptable for reinsurance. 
ADB will also charge a ceding commission to the reinsurers to cover costs associated with 
administering the reinsurance. The ceding commission will be market-based. Both the fee for 
each PRG and the ceding commission will be approved by the Guarantee Committee of ADB.

GRANT RATIONALE AND PURPOSE 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will provide $10 million financing for the Project. 
The Project will assist the Government set up a new institution, Lao Plantation Authority (LPA). 
Since this is a creative new initiative, the Government is requesting a grant of $3 million from 
the Asian Development Fund (ADF) to help finance operations in its formative years. ADF has 
allocated half of the program amount for Lao PDR as grant.1 ADF allocation for the Project is 
identified in the Country Strategy and Program Update 2006–2008. 
 
2.  Rationale. The grant under this Project will be used to establish and then operate LPA 
for the 6-year Project period. Since LPA is being set up as a new semiautonomous institution—
an unprecedented development in Lao PDR—the Government is reluctant to borrow for this 
venture. The grant is justified because LPA will set new standards of excellence by employing 
relatively inexperienced but well-educated and bright local staff at competitive salary packages 
along with performance bonuses. The position of chief technical advisor (CTA) will also be 
funded  with  this  grant.  This  institutional  arrangement  will  ensure  that  requisite  capacity  is 
created to develop the subsector in line with its potential. The Government will ensure its 
financial  sustainability  beyond  the  Project  life  by  providing  it  a  legal  remit,  through  prime 
ministerial decree, to: (i) recover and retain its share of the revenues from investments in 
plantations; (ii) charge for its services and retain its income; and (iii) receive part of the land 
rents, as land management fee, from large industrial plantations (LIPs) to defray its service 
costs. This grant will also catalyze further parallel grant cofinancing from the Government of 
Malaysia, which will second three experts to head three LPA divisions. Therefore, the Project 
grant is a special feature, without which, LPA might not have been established. LPA will play a 
critical role in implementing the Project and developing the plantations subsector efficiently and 
expeditiously. The full-scale model of LPA is described in Supplementary Appendix A. 
 
3.  Proposed  Grant  Activities.  Establishment  of  productive  forest  plantations  requires 
effective land-use planning, extension and training, appropriate modes of financing, and efficient 
marketing. Existing institutions in Lao PDR have weak capacity to provide effective support to 
forest plantations that require a specific set of expertise. Such skills cannot be gained without 
engaging experts with a proven track record from elsewhere and providing hands-on training to 
appropriately compensated and motivated local staff. Therefore, it is necessary to set up an 
institution like LPA that could create the requisite institutional and staff capacity by engaging the 
relevant experts from overseas in the medium term. Given the significant potential of this 
subsector in Lao PDR and the ominous signs of its rapid development, LPA will help the 
Government take advantage of these opportunities. LPA will provide an effective full-package 
service to small livelihood and medium enterprise plantations, and small and medium-sized 
enterprises; and one-window service to LIPs. A semiautonomous and appropriately staffed LPA 
will bridge the capacity gap in a short period and later create capacity among local staff through 
a  staff  transition  plan.  By  the  end  of  the  6-year  Project  period,  LPA  will  be  a  premier 
Government agency mainly staffed by local experts, with the possible exception of the CTA.

context of project performance. The Project’s design and monitoring framework (Appendix 3) 
has clear indicators to measure the inputs, activities, and outputs financed through the grant.

FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC ANALYSES 
A.  Introduction 
1.  The goal of the Project is to reduce poverty and spur economic growth by developing the 
forest plantations subsector in Lao PDR. The immediate purpose is to set up an effective 
institution that supports livelihood plantations and acts as a catalyst to attract large-scale foreign 
direct investment (FDI) for industrial plantations and subsequent development of a modern and 
efficient  wood  processing  industry,  generating  considerable  employment  and  government 
revenues. The bulk of the project funds will be invested in supporting livelihood plantations that 
would significantly contribute to poverty reduction among participating households.  
 
2.  The  Project  will  establish  Lao  Plantation  Authority  (LPA),  whose  business  plan  will 
comprise  three  main  activities:  (i)  support  small  livelihood  plantations  (SLPs),  (ii)  facilitate 
operations  of  large  industrial  plantations  (LIPs),  and  (iii)  promote  plantation  enterprise 
development by supporting medium enterprise plantations (MEPs) and small and medium-sized 
enterprises (SMEs). LPA, as a semiautonomous and financially sustainable body, will be the 
executing agency of the Project. It will provide full-package service to SLPs, MEPs, and SMEs. 
LPA  will  finance  SLPs  and  MEPs  through  an  equity-sharing  model  and  support  business 
development of SMEs through technical assistance. All financing arrangements will be in hard 
currency on market-based terms, and financially viable. No indirect or direct subsidies will be 
needed and none provided.  
 
B.  Project Benefits 
 
3.  The Project will generate a variety of direct, indirect, quantifiable, and nonquantifiable 
benefits. The direct and quantifiable benefits will accrue to SLPs, MEPs, and SMEs. LIPs will 
get direct but unquantifiable benefits as LPA will facilitate land-use survey and planning, and 
negotiate land lease agreements with them on behalf of the Government. LPA’s facilitating role 
will significantly reduce the transaction cost of FDI in this subsector. Plantations of all types will 
generate significant direct employment in down- and upstream trade and supply chains. LIPs 
will generate large sums of revenues in land rents as well as in corporate income and local 
taxes. Similarly, MEPs and SMEs will generate employment and revenues. The most important 
social impact will be on poverty reduction—a direct outcome of SLP operations. Increased 
government revenues will have significant impact on poverty reduction at the national level, as a 
result of increased investments in social development. 
 
C.  Financial and Economic Analysis 
 
1.  Financial Analysis of Plantation Models 
4.  Most direct and quantified benefits of the Project will stem from three main sources: 
(i) return from SLPs; (ii) land rents from LIPs; and (iii) to lesser extent, returns from MEPs and 
SMEs. Financial analyses focus on three plantation models, i.e., SLP, MEP, and LIP. SLPs 
would be established and managed by poor households. Land (3–5 ha per household) will be 
initially allocated by issuing temporary land-use certificates (TLUCs). The size of land allocation 
to each household will depend on the family’s labor availability. The participating household will 
establish a plantation on about one ha per year. MEPs will be established by individuals or small 
companies on their own, leased, or purchased lands. MEPs plantation size would be 50–100 
ha. LIPs would be established on >5,000 ha lands leased from the Government.

5.  To  examine  the  financial  viability,  1-ha  models  for  each  of  these  three  types  of 
plantations have been developed.1 These models are for growing Eucalyptus established and 
managed according to current best practices. Based on field survey of the Industrial Tree 
Plantation Project (ITPP)2 plantations, yield tables for Eucalyptus were generated. Since limited 
data are available for Acacia mangium in Lao PDR, Eucalyptus yield tables can be used for both 
species, with the necessary adjustments. Current market prices for inputs (seedlings, fertilizers, 
insecticides, fencing material, machine rentals, etc.) were used in these models. Daily labor 
wage varies significantly in Vientiane Capital and other provinces. Average wage rate of $1.5 
(KN15,000) per day was used in the analysis. Many potential products from plantation wood 
(fuelwood from thinning and charcoal manufactured from roots and stumps collected during land 
clearing) have good financial value but were not included in the analysis. 
 
6.  Financial analysis was carried out using constant 2005 prices. Input and output prices 
were converted to US dollars at the current exchange rate. The base case uses yield class 
(YC)3 16 for SLPs, YC20 for MEPs, and YC24 for LIPs. The weighted average cost of capital 
was estimated to be about 1%. To estimate the financial internal rate of return (FIRR), a 24-year 
time horizon was used, including original rotation and two coppice rotations. Sensitivity analysis 
was undertaken by varying the key factors, i.e., YC, labor substitution with machinery, log 
prices, and land rents. 
 
7.  The  results  show  that  plantations  are  financially  viable  (Table  A11.1).  Sensitivity 
analyses show that FIRR is sensitive to labor substitution with machinery. This is evident by 
FIRRs for YC20 for all three types of plantations; use/cost of machinery increases from MEP to 
LIP. YC is the most important determinant of financial viability. Therefore, site selection is critical 
for the success of plantations in almost all circumstances. SLPs and MEPs should only be 
established on sites where, at least, YC16 could be attained. Similarly, LIPs should preferably 
plan for, at least, YC20. Proximity to markets is critical for the success of plantations—about half 
of the price at mill-gate 250 km from plantation would, on average, be the transportation cost. 
The Project design has taken this factor into account and introduced the concept of clusters 
(Appendix 4) to ensure adequate density of plantations within reasonable distance, i.e., 25–
75 km to market. For sites of YC20 or better, rotation for 20%–25% of the stock may be 
extended to 10 years (or more) to take advantage of the (30%–35%) higher prices of sawlogs.

that the planter would provide all the labor, LPA will compensate the planter for the full cost of 
labor in year-1, and up to 50% for that of year-2 and year-3. The total payout for labor costs 
during the first 3 years, from LPA to planter, would be $313. Other than direct input costs, LPA’s 
equity will also include $30/ha/year for the first 3 years as the extension service cost, and $10

block plantations would provide further cost reductions and efficiencies in other operations as

2.  Economic Analysis 
18.  The bulk (85%) of the Project investment will be made in SLPs and only modest (3%) in 
MEPs and SMEs; no direct investments will be made in LIPs. There will be quantifiable benefits 
from MEPs and SMEs but they are not included in the economic analysis. Similarly, the return to 
society  from  LIP  operations—resulting  from  employment  and  revenue  generation—will  be 
significant but they are also excluded from this analysis. The economic analysis, therefore, was 
carried out including all LPA costs but the benefits only from SLPs. 
 
a.  Evaluation Methodology and Assumptions 
19.  The economic analysis has been carried out for a project life of 30 years. Constant 2005 
prices were used in US dollars at the current exchange rate. Economic costs and benefits are 
estimated using the world price numeraire. The prices of non-traded goods have been adjusted 
by using a standard conversion factor of 0.9. This is equivalent to using a shadow exchange 
rate factor of 1.1, which has been used in the preparation of other recent Asian Development 
Bank projects in Lao PDR, and is appropriate as it approximately reflects the average level of 
duties  and  taxes.  A  shadow  wage  rate  of  0.8  has  been  used  to  reflect  the  under-  and 
unemployment  rate  in  rural  areas.  For  tractors  and  machinery,  used  in  mechanized  land 
preparation and other operations, taxes and duties account for about 35% of the domestic price. 
For these activities, a conversion factor of 0.65 has been used. The prices of seedlings and 
other domestically produced materials have not been adjusted.

d.  Non-Quantified Economic Benefits 
23.  LPA will strengthen the institutional and staff capacity of the Government to develop the 
plantations subsector. Although capacity building will generate significant benefits in the short

implement these activities and develop the subsector.
