25.  Rodrik has developed a framework of industrial policy.2 Although the development of the 
project concept and the LPA model predate this paper, it is instructive to evaluate the economic 
justification  of  setting  up  LPA  against  his  “10  design  principles  of  industrial  policy” 
(Supplementary Appendix A). Rodrik suggests that “developing societies need to embed private 
initiatives in a framework of public action that encourages restructuring, diversification, and 
technological dynamism beyond what market forces on their own would generate”. He also 
argues “that getting the institutional setting right, with an adequate balance between autonomy 
and embeddedness on the part of Government officials, is far more important than worrying 
about the precise policy instruments to be deployed”. The rationale of setting up LPA and its 
economic justification rest on fundamental principles such as these. 
 
D.  Conclusions 
 
26.  The analysis shows that the Project is financially and economically viable and robust. All 
types and sizes of plantations—SLPs, MEPs, and LIPs—will be financially viable. With the 
financing  mechanism  of  equity-sharing,  LPA  can  recover  adequate  revenues  to  cover  its 
investment and operational costs while providing effective support to its clients and offering 
performance-based incentives for its employees. With and without Project incomes and poverty 
impact  ratios  assure  that  the  Project  will  have  a  significant  poverty  reduction  impact  on 
participating poor households. LPA will generate adequate revenues to upscale its support for 
SLPs beyond the Project life. The economic analysis shows that the Project investment in SLPs 
will be viable and robust, and that the Project has the potential to generate much greater social 
benefits than the value of resource committed for its activities. The support for LPA is justified 
as it has enormous potential to efficiently develop the forest plantations subsector. Proximity to 
markets, quality of plantation lands, and LPA’s semiautonomous management are possible risks

RESETTLEMENT AND ETHNIC MINORITY DEVELOPMENT FRAMEWORKS 
1.  Purpose of Frameworks. The Resettlement Framework (RF) and the Ethnic Minority 
Development Framework (EMDF) have been prepared to identify and compensate all affected 
households, including ethnic minority communities, that may be affected by the development of 
large  industrial  plantations  (LIPs)  and  medium-sized  enterprise  plantations  (MEPs).  Both 
frameworks  have  been  developed  in  accordance  with  various  laws  and  guidelines  of  the 
Government,  ADB’s  policy  on  involuntary  resettlement1  and  policy  on  indigenous  people.2 
These frameworks also build upon principles being developed under other Asian Development 
Bank (ADB)-funded projects in the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR). The RF and 
EMDF will be translated into Lao and distributed to central and local agencies, companies, and 
individuals responsible for developing LIPs and MEPs. These frameworks should also be read 
in conjunction with ADB’s Handbook on Resettlement: A Guide to Good Practice (1998) and 
various relevant Government laws and guidelines. 
 
2.  During project preparation, detailed social and poverty assessments found it necessary 
to prepare the RF and EMDF to safeguard the vulnerable groups against any negative impacts 
of plantation development. As exact sites for LIPs and MEPs will be identified later—after the 
Lao Plantation Authority (LPA) undertakes land-use planning—these frameworks will provide 
fundamental principles upon which detailed resettlement and ethnic minority development plans 
will be prepared to determine entitlements for the affected persons (APs). These plans will 
ensure that (i) rights of all APs are protected during resettlement activities, (ii) ethnic minorities 
are not disadvantaged by virtue of their social and cultural characteristics, and (iii) all APs have 
equal access to project benefits. To ensure that ethnic minority households and villages benefit 
to the same degree as the predominantly Lao Loum villages, a community development plan for 
these villages will be prepared following the EMDF’s principles. All permanent and temporary 
impacts of project activities will be fully addressed. 
 
3.  Government Policies and Laws. This Project will be bound by the principles and 
conditions stated in the RF, and the same will supersede the provisions of relevant decrees in 
force in the Lao PDR wherever a gap exists. In the Lao PDR, compensation principles and 
policy  framework  for  land  acquisition  are  governed  by  several  statutory  laws:  Constitution 
(1991),  Forestry  Law  (1996),  Land  Law  (1997),  and  Road  Law  (1999).  Decree  192  on 
Resettlement and Compensation (July 2005) fully meets the requirements of ADB’s policy on 
involuntary resettlement. Under the Land Law (Articles 17–18 and 21–22), land titles, which 
provide provisional ownership rights to use agricultural as well as forestland, can be issued. All 
APs—whether they have land titles or temporary land-use certificates, or are unregistered—will 
be entitled to compensation for losses caused by the Project.3  
 
4.  Implementation, Monitoring, and Reporting. LPA will be responsible for implementing 
the RF and EMDF and for preparing requisite plans. These plans will be prepared in accordance 
with Government policies, laws, and decrees, and ADB policies. LPA will also be responsible for 
implementing these plans, regularly monitoring them, and reporting to the Government and 
ADB. The preparation and implementation of these plans will be externally monitored during the 
Project’s midterm review.

PROJECT RISKS 
1.  The Project, its operations, and beneficiaries will face a variety of political, institutional, 
market, business, financial, and environmental risks. These risks can be effectively mitigated. 
The risks and their mitigating measures are described below. 
 
A.  Political Risk 
2.  Setting up Lao Plantation Authority (LPA) is an unprecedented and unique experiment in 
Lao PDR. It is a high-risk but high-gain proposition. LPA’s operations will be prone to political 
risks if its autonomy, staffing, and functions are compromised by interference from Government 
officials.  On  the  other  hand,  international  investors  perceive  political  risk  because  of  the 
relatively short time that Lao PDR has been open to foreign investment. The Law on Promotion 
and Management of Foreign Investment, 1994 protects foreign investors against appropriation 
of their assets and there is no reason to believe that the Government would not comply with its 
own law. However, in view of the unforeseen changes that have taken place in other countries, 
this is still perceived as a distinct risk. 
 
3.  Mitigation. LPA’s autonomy will be enshrined in its prime ministerial decree—a sign of 
the  highest-level  Government  commitment.  The  LPA  experiment  is  a  calculated  risk.  The 
Government has provided specific assurances to allow LPA to undertake its operations without 
interference. Specific triggers have been covenanted in the draft Loan Agreement to suspend 
and/or  cancel  LPA  financing  if  operations  deviate  from  its  approved  work  plan.  Its  key 
management staff will have a proven professional track record and provided adequate full-time 
inputs. Moreover, other stakeholders—including nongovernment members of Board of Directors 
(BOD), Asian Development Bank (ADB), and the Government of Malaysia—will provide close 
and regular supervision and monitoring of its operations, especially in the first 2–3 formative 
years. For the political risk of the other kind, Lanxang Oxiana Mines Company and Nam Thuen 
2 Power Company provide two of several other good examples where foreign investors have 
considered  Lao  PDR  a  secure  investment  environment.  ADB  may  provide  a  political  risk 
guarantee (PRG) facility to qualified foreign investors in the plantations subsector. The PRG 
facility procedures and conditions are described in Appendix 5. Besides, establishment of LPA 
in itself would exude confidence among the potential foreign investors. 
 
B.  Institutional Risk 
4.  Most of the investment capital required to establish large industrial plantations (LIPs) and 
associated processing plants will be raised in the international markets. Therefore, foreign 
investors and their bankers will be concerned with the institutional risks of having to deal with 
many  different  Government  agencies.  Weak  institutional  and  staff  capacity  of  Government 
agencies also adds to their transaction costs. Currently, foreign investors face a number of 
institutional difficulties in obtaining approvals for investing in plantations. These mainly relate to 
identifying and leasing suitable land and obtaining a series of licenses and permits. All lands are 
state property in Lao PDR. But the law recognizes traditional and occupational rights of farmers 
and communities. Therefore, obtaining land for plantations involves substantial negotiations with 
local authorities and communities to identify land that does not have claims for other economic 
uses. This is a time-consuming and costly process and has almost certainly been a factor in 
delaying a number of potential investments.

Appendix 13  59 
5.  Mitigation. The Department of Domestic and Foreign Investment (DDFI) is empowered 
to provide a one-stop service to foreign investors in all sectors. This is an important contribution 
to mitigating the institutional risks but it does not cover the identification and negotiation of 
suitable land for plantations. For most foreign investments, in other sectors, only limited areas of 
land  are  required  for  buildings  or  factories.  But  plantations  require  extensive  areas  and, 
therefore,  need  special  consideration.  LPA,  with  requisite  capacity,  and  remit  to  identify, 
negotiate, and lease suitable lands for plantations, will mitigate this risk and reduce transaction 
costs for investors. LPA and DDFI would be able to jointly provide the one-stop service to 
potential investors in this subsector. 
 
C.  Market Risk 
6.  Market risk is minimal as a number of multinational pulp and paper companies are now 
keen to invest in this subsector. Another clear sign that the plantation log markets are coming of 
age is seen along the Route 13 South where a number of procurement depots have sprung up 
in recent months by intermediaries of Thai pulp and paper companies. Although this is still a 
nascent market and information on spot prices, transport costs, and technical parameters (log 
size and moisture content) is still not widely available to most planters, it is well on its way to 
sound development. 
 
7.  Mitigation. LPA design provides for specific assistance to planters to mitigate market 
risk, starting with those of the Industrial Tree Plantation Project (ITPP)1 planters. Through a 
number of initiatives and actions, LPA would ensure that planters get fair prices for their logs. 
One or two wholesale log markets will be established (one near Friendship Bridge in Vientiane 
Capital and another along Route 13 South) to help clear the market through transparent price 
and transaction mechanisms. Information on daily prices, along with technical parameters in 
these  wholesale  markets,  will  help  planters  determine  the  stumpage  price  by  discounting 
harvesting  and  transport  costs—thus  minimizing  the  risk  of  being  duped  by  unscrupulous 
intermediaries. Such market risks mainly apply to individual planters. LIP investors normally 
factor in market risks to their investment decisions. The fact that multinational companies are 
gearing up to establish LIPs would also help mitigate the market risk, as the commitment of 
large amounts of private capital will more or less guarantee markets for plantation log in the 
future. Individual planters also stand to gain from such developments, especially those in the 
proximity of LIPs. In its cluster areas and where ITPP plantations currently stand, LPA will 
provide marketing services. 
 
D.  Business Risk 
8.  There are business (technical) risks that will apply to all types of plantations, i.e., quality 
of planting stock, technical know-how, fire, disease, and adverse whether conditions (drought). 
But experienced plantation managers normally adopt measures to minimize these risks and the 
cost is factored into their business plans. SLPs and MEPs will benefit from the transfer of 
technology from both LPA and LIPs in order to mitigate these risks. 
 
E.  Financial Risk 
9.  In  international  finance  circles,  Lao  PDR  is  perceived  as  a  high-risk  country  for 
investment. This increases the cost of borrowing for investors and may also deter some from

contemplating investments in the country. In addition to these perceived financial risks, the 
transaction costs of working in Lao PDR are considered too high because of delays in obtaining 
approvals and permits, and due to inconsistencies between national laws and regulations and 
the way they are interpreted in the provinces. On the other hand, there are potential financial 
risks for the Government if some of the investors turn out to be unscrupulous or irresponsible. 
The establishment of LPA would also pose some financial risk for the Government if it costs as 
much to set up and does not deliver expected outputs. 
 
10.  Mitigation. There are three ways these risks can be mitigated. First, LPA will be able to 
investigate the transaction costs and have the authority to deal with them by establishing 
common  and  transparent  arrangements  throughout  the  country.  Second,  ADB,  through  its 
private sector operations, may provide cofinancing to qualified foreign investors—spreading and 
mitigating  some  financial  risk.  Third,  financial  risks  to  the  Government  from  potential 
unscrupulous  investors  will  be  mitigated  by  LPA’s  ability  to  undertake  due  diligence 
investigations of potential investors before approval. 
 
F.  Environmental Risk 
11.  A recent comprehensive study on the subject concludes:  
 “Fast-wood forestry is neither inherently good nor inherently bad. It is neutral technology 
which, when poorly planned and executed, can cause grave problems; and which, when 
well planned and executed, can deliver not just large quantities of wood, but a range of 
environmental and social benefits.”2  
History is replete with examples where exotic species of crops and trees have been highly 
successfully adopted in new environments. Adoption of oil palm and rubber trees in Malaysia 
from Brazil in the early 1800s is a prime example in the region. Ironically, both these trees are 
now more successfully cultivated in this region than in their native Brazil (where they are 
enduring a variety of diseases and pest attacks). Conversely, the productivity of Eucalyptus is 
much higher in its adopted environments in Latin America (Chile and Brazil) and South Africa 
than its native Australia. Its productivity was around yield class (YC) 20 in the 1970s when first 
introduced in Brazil, but it now regularly exceeds YC40. Nevertheless, there are bad examples 
of its adoption in many places (the Congo). Despite all its failings, one of the major contributions 
of ITPP is that it has successfully demonstrated that, if Eucalyptus plantations are established 
and managed effectively, they can be environmentally safe and financially viable. 
 
12.  Mitigation. All types of plantations will comprise only a small portion of the mosaic of 
land-use systems in any given location. Even LIPs will not be wall-to-wall plantations, spanning 
hundreds of thousands of hectares (ha) in just one locality. Rather, LIPs will be established in 
blocks of 200–300 ha with buffer zones comprising other land uses, separating them from 
natural forests. Similarly, they would keep a safe distance from streams and other water bodies 
and will not be grown on slopes >20°. A comprehensive set of environmental and technical 
standards and criteria have been prepared as part of LPA’s compliance function. Its plantation 
standards and compliance officer will be responsible for establishing codes of practice and 
monitoring compliance. Regular third party environmental audits will be carried out to monitor 
compliance.
